Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) \\) that evolves according to the differential equation \\( \\dot{z} = i\\omega z \\), where \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit and \\( \\omega \\) is a real constant. The function is transformed using \\( g(z) = e^{\\alpha t}z \\), where \\( \\alpha \\) is a real constant, to analyze its behavior over time.

Can we deduce the original complex number \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0 after observing \\( z(t) \\) at t = T without knowing whether \\( g(z) \\) was applied?
Explanation: Without knowledge of the application of \\( g(z) \\), the scaling effect on the amplitude of \\( z_0 \\) introduced by \\( e^{\\alpha t} \\) remains unknown. This uncertainty prevents uniquely determining the initial value \\( z_0 \\) based solely on the observed \\( z(t) \\) at t = T.

causal_map_integration: The initial value z(0) directly causes the value of z(t) at any time t. Applying the transformation g(z) directly causes the observed value z(t) at any time t.
